Award.AwardTitle: DCL: NSF INCLUDES Conference - Collaborative Research: Envisioning Impact
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a conference that will inform the design of "backbone" organizations for the NSF INCLUDES (Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science) program. NORC at the University of Chicago (an independent research institution that delivers reliable data and rigorous analyses to guide programmatic and policy decisions) and TERC (a nonprofit education research and development organization based in Cambridge, MA, dedicated to improving STEM learning for all) collaborate on Envisioning Impact, a two-part in-person and virtual event that will inform the design of INCLUDES Alliance and National Network backbone organizations.

The objectives of the conference are to: (1) facilitate a shared vision of impact for INCLUDES broadening participation projects and program; (2) stimulate discourse on key elements of a shared measurement system for continuous improvement and outcome assessment; and (3) inform decisions on the infrastructure and priority services INCLUDES backbone organizations will provide to assist grantees (and others) in assessing progress towards collective impact. The conference will bring members of three communities together: PIs and evaluators of INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilots; investigators and evaluators of other NSF-supported broadening participation alliances, extension projects, and other collective efforts to support inclusion and diversity in STEM; and members of prior and extant NSF-supported knowledge-networking, collaboratory, and resource network initiatives. Members of these communities will collaborate in two separate events: an in-person, 1.5 day conference, and a follow-on virtual Video Hall that will allow a larger number of participants to engage, over a one week period, in facilitated community discourse around short video narratives produced by each project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Envisioning Impacts was a collaborative project that included an in-person conference led by NORC at the University of Chicago and a virtual convening led by TERC meant to inform the design of INCLUDES’ Alliance and National Network “backbone” organizations. Our objectives were to: (1) facilitate shared visioning of impact for INCLUDES broadening participation projects and program; (2) stimulate discourse on key elements of a shared measurement system for continuous improvement and outcome assessment; and (3) inform decisions on the infrastructure and priority services INCLUDES’ backbone organizations will provide to assist grantees (and others) in assessing progress towards collective impact. Consistent with INCLUDES’ ethos of collaboration, we invited the first cohort of INCLUDES Launch Pilot projects and multiple communities with expertise on broadening participation to discuss these issues at a 2-day workshop at NORC’s downtown offices in Chicago, Illinois. The conference agenda included 3 panel discussions, 2 plenary sessions, and 4 “partner exercises” where team members from the 14 INCLUDES projects in attendance were assigned to breakout groups to discuss Anticipating Launch Pilots’ Impacts, Partnering for Impact, Documenting Impacts, and Organizing for Impact. The meeting also included an alliance-building exercise that allowed projects to envision the kinds of partners they would need in order to achieve broader impacts. In terms of helping projects envision impacts beyond their two year funding period and situate their work within the larger STEM ecosystem, projects came to understand that the INCLUDES broadening participation effort means, for example, establishing a firm foundation of trust in the communities in which they work, helping minority and disabled students develop a STEM identity that motivates them to pursue a science degree, and, ultimately, changing how the larger community thinks and talks about STEM careers.

The main goal of the Envisioning Impact conference was to provide feedback to the NSF program officers in attendance for guiding the design of INCLUDES Alliance and National Network backbone organizations capable of supporting a collective impact (or related) approach and its shared measurement needs. Here too the discussion was rich and varied. Beyond sharing measures and helping projects think about new metrics for assessing collaboration such as social network analysis, Launch Pilot projects were eager to have a national backbone organization help pull together what we’ve already learning from prior broadening participation initiatives, understand how challenges may vary by STEM subject or pathway, provide strategies for sustaining programs beyond the NSF funding period, synthesize and disseminate findings to catalyze impacts beyond individual projects, and support efforts to build Alliances for changing the national STEM ecosystem. In fact, the latter issue dominated much of the discussion since projects were unsure about how to build such Alliances given their diversity in terms of both project goals and structure, with some projects already having several partners and a long history of collaboration. The conference was successful in highlighting some of the critical dimensions along which projects might find complementary partners, although it was unclear how many such dimensions projects needed to have in common in order to ensure success partnerships or whether there is even a critical mass of INCLUDES projects currently funded to begin the process. Perhaps more cohorts of Launch Pilot projects are needed and additional guidance developed by the national backbone organization before NSF undertakes the formation of Alliances? Such uncertainties notwithstanding, projects seemed to embrace the INCLUDES’ goal of disrupting the usual way of doing things as a precondition for achieving collective impact.
